results.headline: Au Hasard, Balthazar (Movie)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Au Hasard, Balthazar

results.summary_short: Written and directed by Robert Bresson, and shot in limpid black-and-white, this 1966 allegory tracks the journey of two innocents, the teenage Marie (Anna Wiazemsky, who later married Jean-Luc Godard) and the soulful donkey of the film's title that's adopted by her family when she and the animal are very young. In the course of Bresson's short tale, both Marie and Balthazar will endure a crucible of suffering — she at the rough hands of a punk in a black leather jacket, the donkey at the equally rough hands of various vicious masters. The critic J. Hoberman has observed that "Balthazar" is about a donkey in about the same way that "Moby-Dick" is about a whale, but it is also true that this is a story about an animal. Inspired by a passage from Dostoevsky's "Idiot," Bresson makes Balthazar the moral center of his film, perhaps because, unlike Marie and the rest of the men and women in this fallen world, the donkey doesn't need to die to achieve grace. (It's worth noting that Bresson used a Schubert Sonata as "a kind of language for the donkey's soul.") Over the years, some critics have classified Bresson's work as unapproachable, even punishing. For these professional philistines the idea that movies can be serious, more than tricks and trashy entertainment, is apparently anathema. Don't you believe it: "Au Hasard Balthazar" is a masterpiece of the art, but a masterpiece that stirs the heart and soul as much as the mind. — Manohla Dargis

results.headline: End of the Road (Movie)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The End of the Road

results.summary_short: Brent Meeske's hardscrabble documentary follows the last Grateful Dead tour in 1995, but it doesn't follow the band. Its subject is the devotees, the Deadheads who formed shantytown bazaars in the parking lots of arenas and stadiums around the country. For those with a soft spot for the Dead, "The End of the Road" will seem loving and thoughtful. For the rest of us, there's probably not enough oil in Kuwait, tea in China or weed in Marin County to make this film worth our time. -- Mitchell
